unnormalised: Navigating the labyrinthine world of medical titles can feel like deciphering ancient Sanskrit, especially when you’re just trying to book an appointment or understand who’s poking you with a needle. From the revered "Dr." to the slightly intimidating "Prof.," it's a veritable alphabet soup of qualifications and responsibilities. But fear not, fellow patients, for we shall demystify these honorifics with a touch of levity and a sprinkle of chai-induced wisdom.
normalised: Navigating the labyrinthine world of medical titles can feel like deciphering ancient Sanskrit, especially when you’re just trying to book an appointment or understand who’s poking you with a needle. From the revered "Doctor" to the slightly intimidating "Professor," it's a veritable alphabet soup of qualifications and responsibilities. But fear not, fellow patients, for we shall demystify these honorifics with a touch of levity and a sprinkle of chai-induced wisdom.

unnormalised: Let's start with the classics. "Dr." is your general practitioner, the jack-of-all-trades, master of… well, general medicine. Think of them as the Virat Kohli of healthcare – reliable, consistent, and always ready to take on a challenge, whether it's a sniffle or a suspicious mole. Then you have "Prof.," the Gandalf of the medical world. These are the venerable sages who’ve probably forgotten more about medicine than we’ll ever know. They’re often found lecturing students and occasionally dispensing profound wisdom – or just prescribing bed rest and hot water with turmeric. My own GP is Dr. R. Kumar and he refers to Dr. G. Sen, Prof of Cardiology when I need a specialist!

unnormalised: Moving up the hierarchy, we encounter the specialists. There's the "Surgeon," the equivalent of a Bollywood action hero, wielding scalpels instead of swords. They're the ones you want around when things get serious, like needing your appendix evicted or your bones reassembled. Just hope they've had their morning chai before they start slicing! "Specialist" can also mean Dr. S. Iyer, MD in dermatology, or Dr. A. Khan, DNB in Neurology, just to show off a few more acronyms.

unnormalised: Now, for the alphabet soup: MBBS, MS, MD, DM, FRCS, MRCP... it's enough to make your head spin faster than a ceiling fan in a Mumbai summer. These are all different levels of qualifications and specializations. Think of them as badges of honor earned through years of sleep deprivation, caffeine addiction, and memorizing anatomical diagrams that look suspiciously like alien landscapes. But don't worry too much about decoding them – just trust that they know what they're doing. And if they don't, well, that's what second opinions are for!

unnormalised: So, the next time you’re faced with a bewildering array of medical titles, remember this: they’re all just people trying to help, albeit with a lot more initials after their names. Whether it's Dr. Sharma scribbling a prescription or Prof. Patel diagnosing a rare disease, a bit of humor and understanding can go a long way in navigating the often-confusing world of healthcare. And if all else fails, just ask them to explain it to you like you're five – they're used to it.
